# AWS Shared Responsibility Model â€“ Quickâ€‘Reference Learning Material --- ## 1. What is the Shared Responsibility Model? AWS follows a **division of security and compliance duties** between **AWS (the cloud provider)** and **you, the customer**. - **AWS** is responsible for the *security of the cloud* â€“ the underlying infrastructure, regions, Availability Zones, and the services that run on top of that foundation. - **You** are responsible for *security in the cloud* â€“ how you configure, use, and protect the resources you create. Think of it as a **shared fence**: - AWS builds and maintains the fence (the cloud platform). - You decide what to put behind it and how to lock the gate. --- ## 2. Core Components of the Model | Layer | Who is responsible? | What is covered? | |-------|----------------------|------------------| | **Physical / Facility** | **AWS** | Dataâ€‘center power, cooling, physical security, network cabling | | **Network & Infrastructure** | **AWS** | Hypervisor, hyperâ€‘visor layer, virtualization, storage hardware, load balancers, DDoS protection | | **Platform Services** | **AWS** | Managed services (e.g., RDS, DynamoDB, Lambda, S3) â€“ OS patches, runtime updates | | **Customerâ€‘Managed Configurations** | **You** | Guest OS, applications, data, encryption keys, IAM policies, network ACLs, VPC settings | | **Operational Practices** | **You** | Patch management (if you control the OS), backup strategies, incident response, logging, compliance reporting | *(The exact split varies by service â€“ see Sectionâ€¯4.)* --- ## 3. Customer Responsibilities (What *you* must do) | Area | Typical Tasks | |------|----------------| | **Identity & Access Management** | Create IAM users/roles, enforce leastâ€‘privilege, use MFA, manage policies | | **Data Protection** | Encrypt data at rest & in transit, manage KMS keys, apply bucket policies | | **Configuration & Patch Management** | Apply OS/firmware patches (if you control the OS), update runtime libraries | | **Network Security** | Design VPC/subnet layout, security groups, NACLs, DNS, VPN/Direct Connect configurations | | **Logging & Monitoring** | Enable CloudTrail, CloudWatch, GuardDuty, Config, set up alerts | | **Backup & Disaster Recovery** | Define backup schedules, restore tests, multiâ€‘AZ/Region strategies | | **Compliance & Auditing** | Run compliance checks (PCIâ€‘DSS, HIPAA, etc.), retain evidence for auditors | | **Application Security** | Secure code, secrets management, container image scanning, custom IAM roles for Lambda, etc. | | **Resource Lifecycle** | Properly delete or retire resources to avoid â€œorphanedâ€ assets | --- ## 4. AWS Responsibilities (What AWS must do) | Layer | Services/Areas Covered | |-------|------------------------| | **Physical Security** | Dataâ€‘center access control, video surveillance, biometric entry | | **Infrastructure** | Bareâ€‘metal servers, networking (switches, routers), storage hardware | | **Compute & Hosting** | EC2 hypervisor, EBS, EFS, S3 storage durability, Lambda execution environment | | **Network Foundations** | VPC networking, Route 53 DNS, CloudFront edge locations | | **Managed Services** | RDS patching, DynamoDB scaling, S3 durability, Elastic Beanstalk, ECS/EKS orchestration | | **Security Services** | IAM, KMS, Secrets Manager, WAF, Shield, GuardDuty, Macie | | **Compliance & Certifications** | Provide audit reports (SOC, ISO, PCI, etc.) and underlying controls | | **Patch & Update Management** | Apply underlying OS/hypervisor patches for managed services | --- ## 5. How Responsibilities Shift Across Popular Services | Service | What **AWS** Handles | What **You** Must Handle | |---------|----------------------|--------------------------| | **Amazon EC2** | â€¢ Underlying hardware, hypervisor, networking fabric
â€¢ EC2 instance OS image (AMI) baseline patches
â€¢ Availability & scaling of EC2 control plane | â€¢ Choosing AMI, OS version, installing updates
â€¢ Configuring security groups, key pairs
â€¢ Encrypting EBS volumes (KMS)
â€¢ Installing application patches | | **Amazon RDS** | â€¢ Database engine patches, backups, automated failover, read replicas
â€¢ Underlying storage & network | â€¢ Choosing DB engine & version
â€¢ Setting encryption at rest & in transit
â€¢ Managing DB credentials, IAM DB authentication
â€¢ Configuring DBâ€‘level access, parameter groups | | **AWS Lambda** | â€¢ Runtime environment, automatic scaling, underlying compute
â€¢ Patching of Lambda platform | â€¢ Uploading code (zip/container), environment variables
â€¢ Managing function permissions (IAM role)
â€¢ Configuring VPC attachment, layers, and environment security | | **Amazon S3** | â€¢ Object durability & availability, encryptionâ€‘atâ€‘rest options, S3â€‘level access controls | â€¢ Bucket policies, ACLs, SSEâ€‘KMS/SSEâ€‘C (customerâ€‘managed keys)
â€¢ Objectâ€‘level encryption keys (if using clientâ€‘side encryption)
â€¢ Lifecycle rules, versioning, access logging | | **AWS Fargate / ECS/EKS** | â€¢ Container runtime, underlying EC2 hosts, OS patches | â€¢ Container image security, ECR repository policies
â€¢ Taskâ€‘level IAM roles, serviceâ€‘level networking (security groups)
â€¢ Orchestration config (task definitions) | | **AWS Glue / Athena** | â€¢ Managed Spark/Presto engines, query execution, metadata store | â€¢ Defining IAM roles, data catalog permissions, encryption settings | | **AWS IAM** | â€¢ Identity service itself (no responsibilities) | â€¢ All IAM policy creation, role assumption, password policies, MFA, access key rotation | *Key Takeaway:* **The more â€œmanagedâ€ the service, the smaller the slice you own.** Conversely, when you run your own compute (EC2, selfâ€‘managed databases), you own a larger portion of the stack. --- ## 6. Visual Summary (Simplified Fence Analogy) ``` +------------------------------------------------------------+ | AWS (Provider) | | â€¢ Physical dataâ€‘center, power, cooling | | â€¢ Network fabric, hypervisor, storage hardware | | â€¢ Managed services (RDS, Lambda, S3, etc.) | +------------------------------------------------------------+ | YOU (Customer) | | â€¢ IAM policies, encryption keys, OS/app patches | | â€¢ VPC/subnet design, security groups, ACLs | | â€¢ Backup, logging, compliance, incident response | +------------------------------------------------------------+ ``` --- ## 7. Quick Checklist â€“ â€œAm I Covered?â€ | âœ… | Question | Typical Answer | |----|----------|----------------| | 1 | **Do I need to patch the OS?** | Only if Iâ€™m using EC2 or selfâ€‘managed containers. | | 2 | **Who encrypts the data at rest?** | I can use AWSâ€‘managed keys (SSEâ€‘S3) or my own (SSEâ€‘KMS). | | 3 | **Who controls who can call my API?** | I define IAM policies / resourceâ€‘based policies. | | 4 | **Who ensures high availability of the underlying platform?** | AWS guarantees multiâ€‘AZ/Region redundancy for managed services. | | 5 | **Who maintains the physical security of the data center?** | AWS. | If you can answer â€œYesâ€ to the appropriate column, youâ€™re aligned with the shared model for that service. --- ## 8. Why It Matters - **Compliance:** Auditors (e.g., PCIâ€‘DSS) require proof that youâ€™ve taken the responsibilities assigned to you. - **Risk Management:** Misâ€‘configurations in the â€œcustomerâ€ layer are the most common cause of breaches. - **Cost Control:** Overâ€‘provisioning security controls in the AWS layer you donâ€™t own can lead to unnecessary spend. - **Incident Response:** Knowing the boundary helps you decide where to focus forensic analysis (e.g., CloudTrail vs. EC2 logs). --- ### TL;DR - **AWS** = **Security of the cloud** (hardware, hypervisor, managed services). - **You** = **Security in the cloud** (configurations, data, access, patching where applicable). - The exact split shifts per service: **EC2 â†’ more customer control**, **RDS/Lambda/S3 â†’ more AWS control**. - Use the checklist and visual â€œfenceâ€ to quickly map responsibilities for any new AWS service you adopt. --- *Prepared for AWS training & certification prep â€“ concise enough for a quick review, yet comprehensive enough to cover all required knowledge points.*

## AWS Compute Services â€“ Quickâ€‘Reference Learning Material  

### 1.â€¯Amazonâ€¯EC2 â€“ Virtual Machines

| **Storageâ€‘optimized** (e.g., **i3**, **i4i**, **d2**) | High local SSD I/O, large local disk capacity | NoSQL stores, data warehouses, log aggregation | Store terabytes of clickâ€‘stream data on an **i3.4xlarge** |

**Key takeâ€‘aways**

### 2.â€¯Containers â€“ Managed Orchestration  

| Service | Core Concept | When to Use | Notable Features |
|---------|--------------|------------|------------------|
| **Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS)** | Fullyâ€‘managed container orchestration with two launch types: **EC2** and **Fargate** | Simple microâ€‘service architectures, liftâ€‘andâ€‘shift of Docker workloads | Tight integration with IAM, CloudWatch, and ALB; supports serviceâ€‘level scaling |

| **AWS Fargate** (serverless compute for containers) | Serverless compute engine that runs containers without managing instances | Want to focus purely on code, not on EC2 provisioning; bursty or shortâ€‘lived workloads | Automatic scaling, perâ€‘task CPU/memory billing, builtâ€‘in security isolation |

**Practical tip**

### 3.â€¯Serverless Compute  

| Service | Execution Model | Ideal Scenarios | Billing Granularity |
|---------|----------------|----------------|---------------------|
| **AWS Lambda** | Eventâ€‘driven functions (up to 15â€¯min) | Shortâ€‘lived request/response logic, data transformations, scheduled tasks | Perâ€‘invocation, perâ€‘GBâ€‘second of memory used |
| **AWS Fargate (container)** | Serverless containers (up to 4â€¯h) | Longerâ€‘running services, background jobs, APIs that need more control than Lambda | Same perâ€‘vCPU/GBâ€‘second model as EC2 but no instance mgmt |
| **AWS Batch** | Managed batchâ€‘processing jobs on EC2/Fargate | Highâ€‘throughput ETL, scientific simulations, rendering farms | Pay for the compute resources you consume |

### 4.â€¯Auto Scaling â€“ Elasticity in Action  

| Autoâ€‘Scaling Mechanism | What It Does | Typical Trigger Types | Example Configuration |
|------------------------|--------------|-----------------------|-----------------------|
| **EC2 Auto Scaling Groups (ASG)** | Maintains a minimum/desired/maximum number of EC2 instances across AZs | CPU/Memory thresholds, request count per target, schedule, predictive scaling | `DesiredCapacity=3`, `Min=1`, `Max=10`, scaling policy `TargetTrackingScaling` on `CPUUtilization > 70%` |

**Key principle** â€“ *Scale out before you scale up* (i.e., add capacity ahead of load) and *scale in after traffic subsides* to control cost.

### 5.â€¯Load Balancers â€“ Traffic Distribution  

| Load Balancer Type | Layer (OSI) | Primary Useâ€‘Case | Notable Features |
|--------------------|------------|------------------|------------------|

| **Network Load Balancer (NLB)** | Layerâ€¯4 (TCP/UDP, TLS) | Ultraâ€‘lowâ€‘latency, highâ€‘throughput traffic, UDP/TCP services, static IP requirement | Fixed IP, supports Elastic IP, can handle millions of connections, supports TLS termination |

---

## Putting It All Together â€“ A Miniâ€‘Architecture Blueprint  

1. **Compute Layer**  
   - Deploy **ECS services** (Fargate) for stateless APIs.  
   - Run **EKS** with **Fargate profiles** for stateful microâ€‘services requiring custom networking.  
   - Use **EC2** instances of the appropriate family (e.g., `c5.2xlarge` for CPUâ€‘heavy batch jobs).  

2. **Elasticity**

   - Enable **Predictive Scaling** on ASGs for predictable daily/weekly patterns.  

3. **Traffic Management**

   - Use **NLB** for a highâ€‘throughput, lowâ€‘latency service such as a WebSocket chat backend.  

4. **Serverless Addâ€‘ons**  
   - Offload sporadic jobs (e.g., image thumbnail generation) to **Lambda** with **Provisioned Concurrency**.  
   - Use **Step Functions** to orchestrate multiâ€‘step workflows that span Lambda, ECS, and EC2.  

5. **Observability**

---

### Quick Reference Cheatâ€‘Sheet  

| Concept | Service | Typical Useâ€‘Case | Scaling Mechanism |
|---------|---------|------------------|-------------------|
| Virtual Machines | EC2 | Legacy apps, custom OS, GPU workloads | ASG + Scaling Policies |
| Containers | ECS/Fargate, EKS | Microâ€‘service APIs, batch jobs | Service Auto Scaling, Cluster Autoscaler |
| Serverless Functions | Lambda | Eventâ€‘driven code, scheduled jobs | Provisioned Concurrency, concurrency limits |
| Batch Processing | AWS Batch, Fargate | ETL, data transformation | Job queue + Compute Environment scaling |
| Load Balancing | ALB, NLB | HTTP routing, highâ€‘throughput TCP | Integrated with ASG/ECS, target groups |
| Elasticity | Auto Scaling Groups, Predictive Scaling | Respond to traffic spikes | CloudWatch metrics â†’ scaling actions |

---

**Bottom line:**  
- **Match the service to the workloadâ€™s dominant resource** (CPU, memory, storage, or accelerator).  
- **Leverage managed scaling** (Auto Scaling, Service Auto Scaling, Lambda concurrency) to keep capacity elastic without manual intervention.  
- **Frontâ€‘end traffic** should be routed through the appropriate load balancer, which then distributes requests to the correctlyâ€‘scaled compute tier.  

Use this material as a foundation for designing costâ€‘effective, highlyâ€‘available, and scalable architectures on AWS. Happy building!

Quickâ€‘Reference Cheat Sheet | Category | Feature | Key Identifier / Command | |----------|---------|--------------------------| | **VPC** | CIDR block (e.g., `10.0.0.0/16`) | `aws ec2 describe-vpcs` | | **Subnet** | Public vs. Private (route to IGW) | `aws ec2 describe-subnets` | | **IGW** | Attaches VPC to Internet | `aws ec2 create-internet-gateway` | | **NAT** | Outbound Internet for private subnets | `aws ec2 create-nat-gateway` | | **Route Table** | Default `0.0.0.0/0 â†’ IGW` | `aws ec2 describe-route-tables` | | **Security Group** | Stateful, perâ€‘ENI | `aws ec2 authorize-security-group-ingress` | | **Network ACL** | Stateless, perâ€‘subnet | `aws ec2 create-network-acl` | | **Route 53 Hosted Zone** | `example.com` (public/private) | `aws route53 create-hosted-zone` | | **VPN** | Customer gateway â†”ï¸ Virtual private gateway | `aws ec2 create-vpn-connection` | | **Direct Connect** | Physical port on AWS side | `aws directconnect create-connection` | | **Transit Gateway** | Central hub for many attachments | `aws ec2 create-transit-gateway` | --- ### 6. Putting It All Together â€“ Typical Architecture Diagram (textual) ``` [Onâ€‘Premises] â”€â”€ VPN/Direct Connect â”€â”€> [Transit Gateway] â”€â”€> (VPC A) â”€â”€> [VPC B (peered)] â”‚ â””â”€> [Internet] â”€â”€> [Elastic Load Balancer] â”€â”€> [EC2 (public subnet)] â”‚ â””â”€> [RDS (private subnet)] â”‚ â””â”€> [Route 53 (public hosted zone + private zone)] ``` - **Security:** SG on EC2, NACL on private subnet, optional Network Firewall. - **DNS:** Public Routeâ€¯53 records point to ELB; internal services resolved via private hosted zone. - **Connectivity:** VPN for quick start; upgrade to Direct Connect + TGW when traffic scales. --- ## TL;DR Summary | What to Remember | |------------------| | **VPC** = isolated network; key pieces: subnets, IGW, NAT, route tables, peering, endpoints. | | **Security** = **Security Groups** (instance) + **Network ACLs** (subnet) + optional **Inspector**/**Firewall**. | | **Routeâ€¯53** = DNS + healthâ€‘aware routing (simple, weighted, latency, failover, geolocation). | | **Connectivity** = **VPN** (quick, cheap) vs. **Direct Connect** (dedicated, highâ€‘throughput); both can be centralized with **Transit Gateway**. | Use this cheat sheet as a mental map when designing, troubleshooting, or studying for AWS networkingâ€‘focused exam topics. ## 1. What is an API?
- **Application Programming Interface** â€“ a contract that lets two software components talk to each other.
- Exposes **functions / data** over a network using a **requestâ€‘response** pattern.
- In the cloud, APIs are usually **HTTPâ€‘based** (REST, GraphQL, WebSocket) and managed by services like **Amazon API Gateway**.

---

## 2. Core Concepts

| Concept | What It Means | Typical AWS Piece |
|---------|---------------|-------------------|
| **Endpoint** | URL where calls are sent (e.g., `https://x.api.example.com`) | API Gateway Stage (`/prod`, `/dev`) |
| **Method** | HTTP verb (`GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE`, `PATCH`) | Integration request/response mapping |
| **Resource** | Logical grouping of related methods (e.g., `/users`) | API Gateway Resource |
| **Request / Response** | Payload (JSON, XML, binary) that travels in/out of the call | Integration Request/Response Templates |
| **Authentication / Authorization** | Proving who you are and what you can do | IAM, Cognito User Pools, Custom Authorizers, JWT, API Keys |
| **Rate Limiting & Throttling** | Controlling traffic to protect downstream services | Usage Plans, API Keys, AWS WAF |
| **Versioning** | Keeping backwardâ€‘compatible changes separate | URL version (`/v1/...`), Header version, Separate stage/Deployment |
| **Documentation** | Autoâ€‘generated spec for developers | OpenAPI (Swagger) â†’ API Gateway Docs |
| **Observability** | Seeing whatâ€™s happening in production | CloudWatch Metrics, Xâ€‘Ray Traces, Access Logs |

---

## 3. Common API Types & When to Use Them

| API Type | Typical Useâ€‘Case | AWS Service |
|----------|------------------|------------|
| **REST (HTTP/JSON)** | Simple CRUD, public web services | **API Gateway (REST API)** |
| **HTTP (Lowâ€‘latency)** | Highâ€‘throughput, costâ€‘sensitive traffic | **API Gateway (HTTP API)** |
| **WebSocket** | Realâ€‘time bidirectional messaging (chat, dashboards) | **API Gateway WebSocket API** |
| **GraphQL** | Flexible clientâ€‘driven queries, reduce overâ€‘fetching | **AppSync** (managed GraphQL) |

| **Eventâ€‘Driven (SQS/SNS â†’ API)** | Decoupled workflows, fanâ€‘out patterns | **SQS/SNS** + **Lambda** + **API Gateway** (as consumer) |

---

## 4. Key AWS Building Blocks

| Service | Role in API Architecture |
|---------|--------------------------|
| **API Gateway** | Create, publish, maintain, monitor, and secure REST, HTTP, WebSocket, and Lambdaâ€‘proxy APIs. |
| **AWS Lambda** | Serverless compute that can be invoked directly by API Gateway (or via Event Sources). |
| **AWS AppSync** | Managed GraphQL service with realâ€‘time subscriptions, offline data sync, and builtâ€‘in auth (Cognito, IAM, API key). |
| **Amazon Cognito** | User pools & identity pools for authentication, JWT authorizers, and federated signâ€‘in. |
| **AWS IAM** | Fineâ€‘grained access control for serviceâ€‘toâ€‘service calls (SigV4, temporary credentials). |
| **AWS CloudFormation / CDK** | Infrastructureâ€‘asâ€‘code to versionâ€‘control API definitions and deployments. |
| **Amazon CloudWatch** | Metrics, logs, alarms, and custom dashboards for API health & performance. |
| **AWS Xâ€‘Ray** | Endâ€‘toâ€‘end request tracing across Lambda, DynamoDB, downstream services. |
| **AWS WAF** | Web Application Firewall to protect APIs from common attacks (SQLi, XSS, bots). |

---

## 5. Typical API Design Flow (Stepâ€‘byâ€‘Step)

1. **Define Business Goal** â€“ e.g., â€œExpose user profile data to mobile apps.â€
2. **Choose API Type** â€“ REST vs HTTP vs GraphQL vs WebSocket.
3. **Sketch OpenAPI (Swagger) Spec** â€“ endpoints, methods, request/response schemas.
4. **Select Auth Model** â€“ Cognito User Pool + JWT, IAM, or API Key.
5. **Create API in API Gateway** â€“ resources, methods, integration with Lambda (or HTTP/HTTPS backend).
6. **Configure Integration** â€“ map request/response bodies, enable payload logging if needed.
7. **Set Up Authorizers / Policies** â€“ attach Cognito authorizer, IAM role, or custom Lambda authorizer.
8. **Add Throttling / Usage Plans** â€“ limit calls per API key or per stage.
9. **Deploy to Stage** (`dev`, `test`, `prod`) and associate a Custom Domain (optional).

---

## 6. Best Practices

### 6.1 Design & Documentation

- Keep **OpenAPI spec** upâ€‘toâ€‘date; use tools like `swagger-cli` or AWS SAM to validate.
- Use **consistent naming** (`/users/{id}`, `GET /orders?status=shipped`).

### 6.2 Security
- **Never expose AWS secret keys** in clientâ€‘side code. Use Cognito or IAMâ€‘based temporary credentials.
- Apply **leastâ€‘privilege IAM policies** for Lambda/Integration roles.

### 6.4 Reliability

### 6.5 Observability

- **Custom Metrics** for business KPIs (e.g., `UserSignupsPerMinute` via Lambda putMetric).
- Set **alarms** on error rate >â€¯1% or latency >â€¯2â€¯s.

### 6.6 Lifecycle & DevOps

- Use **CI/CD pipelines** (CodePipeline, GitHub Actions) to automatically deploy new versions.
- Perform **canary deployments** (stage variables) before full rollout.
- Rotate **API keys** and **Cognito user pool credentials** periodically.

---

## 7. Quick Reference Cheatâ€‘Sheet (Oneâ€‘Pager)

| Topic | Key Point | AWS Service |
|-------|-----------|-------------|
| **REST API** | Fullâ€‘featured, custom domain, detailed mapping templates | API Gateway (REST) |
| **HTTP API** | Lower latency, cheaper, native OpenAPI support | API Gateway (HTTP) |

| **Deployment** | CI/CD â†’ CloudFormation/CDK | CloudFormation, CDK, SAM |

---

### TL;DR

- **APIs** expose functionality over HTTP; in AWS theyâ€™re mostly built with **API Gateway** (REST/HTTP), **AppSync** (GraphQL), or **Lambda Function URLs**.

## 2. Key Concepts You Must Know  

| Concept | What It Means on AWS | Why It Matters |
|---------|----------------------|----------------|
| **Managed Service** | AWS handles patching, backups, scaling, HA, encryption at rest & inâ€‘flight. | Reduces operational overhead & risk of human error. |
| **Multiâ€‘AZ / Multiâ€‘Region Replication** | Automatic failover to a standby replica in another AZ; crossâ€‘region read replicas for DR. | Guarantees business continuity. |
| **Automatic Backups & Snapshots** | Continuous backup to S3 (up to 35â€¯days) with pointâ€‘inâ€‘time recovery. | Enables quick recovery from mistakes or data corruption. |
| **Read Replicas** | Asynchronous copy of primary DB for read scaling (RDS, Aurora, DynamoDB Global Tables). | Improves read throughput without adding compute to primary. |
| **Elastic Storage Scaling** | Storage autoâ€‘grows (RDS, Aurora) or can be provisioned onâ€‘demand (DynamoDB). | Avoids capacity planning bottlenecks. |
| **Encryption** | Default encryption at rest (KMSâ€‘managed) and inâ€‘flight (TLS). | Meets compliance (PCIâ€‘DSS, HIPAA, GDPR). |

| **Highâ€‘traffic microservice with simple keyâ€‘value access** | DynamoDB (onâ€‘demand) | Millisecond latency, unlimited scale, no server management. |

## 4. Bestâ€‘Practice Checklist  

### 4.1 Design & Architecture  
1. **Pick the right data model** â€“ relational vs. NoSQL vs. columnar vs. graph.  
2. **Model for query patterns first** â€“ design tables/partitions around the most common queries (e.g., partition key for DynamoDB).  
3. **Use managed services where possible** â€“ reduces patching, backups, and scaling chores.  
4. **Leverage read replicas or autoâ€‘scaling** to separate read/write workloads.  

### 4.2 Security  
- Enable **encryption at rest** (KMSâ€‘managed) and **TLS** for inâ€‘flight traffic.  
- Use **IAM roles** and **Secrets Manager** to store credentials; rotate regularly.  
- Apply **leastâ€‘privilege** IAM policies for programmatic access.

### 4.3 Performance & Scalability  
- **Set appropriate provisioned IOPS** (RDS) or **choose onâ€‘demand capacity mode** (DynamoDB) for predictable latency.  
- Use **autoâ€‘scaling storage** (RDS Aurora, DynamoDB) to avoid â€œoutâ€‘ofâ€‘spaceâ€ errors.  
- Enable **caching layers** (ElastiCache, CloudFront + DynamoDB) to offload hot data.  
- Monitor **CloudWatch metrics** (CPU, IOPS, latency, replica lag) and set alarms.  

### 4.4 Data Durability & Backup  
- Enable **automated backups** and **pointâ€‘inâ€‘time recovery** (PITR) for RDS/Aurora.  
- Take **manual snapshots** before major schema changes or upgrades.  
- For DynamoDB, enable **continuous backups** and **pointâ€‘inâ€‘time recovery** (if needed).  
- Use **crossâ€‘region read replicas** for missionâ€‘critical databases.  

### 4.5 Cost Management  
- Choose **onâ€‘demand** for unpredictable workloads; **reserved capacity** or **Savings Plans** for steady traffic.  
- Use **DynamoDB onâ€‘demand** for spiky read/write patterns to avoid overâ€‘provisioning.  
- Rightâ€‘size **instance classes** (db.* or serverless) based on monitoring.  
- Clean up **unused read replicas, snapshots, and old backups**.  

### 4.6 Monitoring & Operations  
- **CloudWatch Alarms** for CPU, freeable memory, replica lag, and error rates.  
- **RDS Performance Insights** (or DynamoDB metrics) to identify slow queries.  
- Use **AWS Config** or **AWS Security Hub** to audit compliance posture.  
- Implement **blue/green deployment** strategies for schema changes (e.g., add new column, then switch traffic).

- **Pick the service that matches your data model** (SQL â†’ RDS/Aurora, keyâ€‘value â†’ DynamoDB, analytics â†’ Redshift, caching â†’ ElastiCache, graph â†’ Neptune, document â†’ DocumentDB, wideâ€‘column â†’ Keyspaces).

## 3. Best Practices  

### 3.1 Planning & Discovery  
1. **Inventory Everything** â€“ Use AWS Application Discovery Service or thirdâ€‘party tools to capture server, DB, and network topology.  
2. **Define Migration Goals** â€“ RTO/RPO, cost constraints, compliance, and performance targets drive service selection.  
3. **Map Dependencies** â€“ Identify interâ€‘service relationships (e.g., DB â†” app server) to schedule cutâ€‘over correctly.  

### 3.2 Choose the Right Tool  
| Data Size / Type | Recommended Transfer Mechanism |
|------------------|--------------------------------|
| <â€¯10â€¯TB, low latency network | Direct Connect / VPN + DMS or Storage Transfer Family |
| 10â€¯TBâ€¯â€“â€¯100â€¯TB | Snowball (or Snowmobile for >â€¯100â€¯TB) |
| >â€¯100â€¯TB, intermittent bandwidth | Snow Family + multipart upload with AWS CLI/S3 Transfer Acceleration |

### 3.3 Security & Compliance  
- **Encrypt Inâ€‘Transit** â€“ Use TLS/SSL for VPN, Direct Connect, or Snowballâ€™s builtâ€‘in encryption.  
- **Encrypt Atâ€‘Rest** â€“ Enable SSEâ€‘S3, SSEâ€‘KMS, or SSEâ€‘C for S3 buckets; use KMSâ€‘encrypted EBS volumes for EC2.  
- **IAM Leastâ€‘Privilege** â€“ Grant only the required permissions to migration roles (e.g., `s3:PutObject`, `dms:CreateReplicationTask`).

1. **Checksum Verification** â€“ Compare MD5/Etag values before and after transfer.

3. **Gradual Traffic Shift** â€“ Use Routeâ€¯53 weighted routing or CloudFront to shift a percentage of traffic before full cutâ€‘over.  
4. **Rollback Plan** â€“ Keep the source environment running (or snapshot) until you confirm stability in AWS.

- **Infrastructure as Code** â€“ Use CloudFormation, Terraform, or CDK to provision target resources (VPC, EC2, RDS, S3) consistently.

## 2. Key Concepts  

| Concept | What It Means on AWS | Practical Implication |
|---------|----------------------|-----------------------|
| **Object vs. Block vs. File** | *Object* (S3) = keyâ€‘value store, accessed via HTTP/HTTPS; *Block* (EBS) = raw disk attached to a single EC2; *File* (EFS/FSx) = shared POSIX/Windows file system. | Choose based on access pattern: object for static assets, block for databases, file for shared home directories. |

## 6. Sample IaC Snippet (Terraform) â€“ Create a Secure, Versioned S3 Bucket  

```hcl
resource "aws_s3_bucket" "secure_data" {
  bucket = "my-company-secure-data"
  force_destroy = false

  # Enable versioning & encryption
  versioning {
    enabled = true
  }

  server_side_encryption_configuration {
    rule {
      apply_server_side_encryption_by_default {
        sse_algorithm = "aws:kms"
        kms_master_key_id = aws_kms_key.data_key.arn
      }
    }
  }

  # Block public access
  block_public_acls       = true
  block_public_policy     = true
  ignore_public_acls      = true
  restrict_public_buckets = true

  # Lifecycle: move >30d to IA, >365d to Glacier
  lifecycle_rule {
    id      = "transition-to-ia-and-glacier"
    enabled = true

    transition {
      days          = 30
      storage_class = "standard-ia"
    }

    transition {
      days          = 365
      storage_class = "glacier"
    }

    expiration {
      days = 365 * 2   # delete after 2 years
    }
  }

  tags = {
    Environment = "prod"
    Owner       = "data-eng"
  }
}
```

*This snippet demonstrates bestâ€‘practice defaults: encryption, versioning, publicâ€‘access blocks, and lifecycle automation.*

## 7. Frequently Asked â€œWhatâ€‘Ifâ€ Scenarios  

| Question | Answer |
|----------|--------|
| **Can I store relational database data directly in S3?** | Not recommended for transactional workloads; use RDS or DynamoDB. S3 can be used for dump/backup files or for analytics (e.g., Athena). |
| **What happens if I delete an S3 bucket that has replication enabled?** | Deleting the source bucket *does* delete the replica in the destination bucket unless you have a replication configuration with **Delete Marker** protection or you use **Object Lock**. |
| **Do EBS volumes persist after the EC2 instance terminates?** | Yes, if they are **not** set to **Delete on Termination**. You can reâ€‘attach them to another instance. |
| **Can I mount an EFS file system on an EC2 instance in a different AZ?** | Yes, but you must use the **regional DNS name** that resolves to an IP in the target AZ; crossâ€‘AZ access incurs additional dataâ€‘transfer costs. |
| **Is there a limit on the number of objects in a bucket?** | Practically unlimited (namespace is 2â¶Â³ objects). You can have up to 5â€¯500â€¯PUT/COPY/DELETE/lists per second per prefix. |
| **How do I handle large file uploads (>â€¯5â€¯GB) efficiently?** | Use **Multipart Upload** (up to 10â€¯GB per part, 10â€¯000 parts). Initiate, upload parts in parallel, then complete. S3 automatically retries failed parts. |

## 4ï¸âƒ£ Sample Design Walkâ€‘through  

**Scenario:** An eâ€‘commerce platform needs to store **order** data with the following access patterns:

1. **Primary Table** â€“ `Orders`

Actually we need a separate sort key for ordering; we can use `order_date` as the **sort key** and keep `customer_id` as part of the partition key? DynamoDB only allows one partition key and one sort key.  

   Better approach:  
   - Partition Key: `customer_id` (string) â€“ groups all orders per customer.  
   - Sort Key: `order_id` (string) â€“ still unique per order, but we can also store `order_date` as an attribute.  

   *Problem:* To query â€œall orders for a customer sorted by dateâ€ we need a **sort key that can be ordered**. Use `order_date` as the sort key **and** store `order_id` as an attribute. However we also need to retrieve a specific order by `order_id`.

2. **Capacity** â€“ Provision 2,000 read and 2,000 write capacity units; enable **Auto Scaling**.  

3. **Consistency** â€“ Use **Eventual Consistency** for listing orders (cheaper) and **Strongly Consistent** only when fetching a single order by `order_id`.

## AWS CodePipeline â€“ Quickâ€‘Start Learning Guide  

---  

### 1ï¸âƒ£ What is CodePipeline?  
A **fullyâ€‘managed continuous delivery service** that orchestrates the steps required to get your code from source repository to production (or any target environment).  

| Core Idea | How it works |
|-----------|--------------|
| **Pipeline** | A linear (or branched) workflow that moves *artifacts* from one **stage** to the next. |
| **Stage** | A logical grouping of **actions** (e.g., Source â†’ Build â†’ Test â†’ Deploy). |
| **Action** | A discrete step performed by a service (e.g., pull from S3, run a build, run unit tests, deploy to EC2). |
| **Artifact** | The output (ZIP, Docker image, CloudFormation change set, etc.) that is passed to the next action. |
| **Source** | Any Gitâ€‘compatible repository (CodeCommit, GitHub, Bitbucket, etc.). |
| **Integrations** | Builtâ€‘in connectors to CodeBuild, CodeDeploy, Lambda, ECS, EKS, Elastic Beanstalk, CloudFormation, S3, etc. |

---  

### 2ï¸âƒ£ Typical Useâ€‘Cases  

| Scenario | Why CodePipeline fits |
|----------|-----------------------|
| **Microâ€‘service CI/CD** | Each service can have its own pipeline; pipelines can be chained for endâ€‘toâ€‘end deployments. |
| **Serverless apps (Lambda, Step Functions, S3)** | Deploy Lambda code or SAM templates directly from source; trigger downstream steps on tag creation. |
| **Blue/Green & Canary Deployments** | Use **CodeDeploy** actions with **DeploymentConfig** (e.g., `CodeDeployDefault.AllAtOnce` or `Canary10Percent50Percent`). |
| **Multiâ€‘language / Multiâ€‘platform** | Combine **CodeBuild** (Docker, custom runtimes) with **ECS/EKS/EC2** deployment actions. |
| **Infrastructureâ€‘asâ€‘Code (IaC) rollout** | Trigger **CloudFormation** stack updates or **CDK** synth â†’ `cfnapply` actions. |
| **Featureâ€‘flag rollout** | Deploy new code behind a flag; use separate stages for â€œEnable flagâ€ (Lambda or manual approval). |
| **Regulated/Compliance pipelines** | Insert **manual approval** stages, audit logs (CloudTrail), and separate IAM roles per stage. |

---  

### 3ï¸âƒ£ Key Concepts & Terminology  

| Term | Meaning |
|------|---------|
| **Pipeline** | The entire workflow definition (JSON/YAML UI). |
| **Stage** | Logical grouping; at least one **Source** and one **Deploy** stage recommended. |
| **Action** | A single operation (e.g., *Source*, *Build*, *Test*, *Deploy*, *Approval*). |
| **Artifact Store** | Where intermediate files are stored (default: S3 bucket). |
| **Source Artifact** | The version of code that enters the pipeline (e.g., a Git commit). |
| **Destination Artifact** | The output of a stage that becomes input to the next stage. |
| **IAM Role for Pipeline** | Grants the pipeline permission to call other AWS services. |
| **Pipeline Execution** | One run of the pipeline from source to final deployment. |
| **Pipeline Versioning** | Each change to the pipeline definition is a new version (you can versionâ€‘control the pipeline JSON in CodeCommit). |

---  

### 4ï¸âƒ£ Architecture Overview (Text Diagram)

```
[Source] --> [Build] --> [Test] --> [Deploy] --> [Postâ€‘Deploy (e.g., Canary, Monitoring)]
   ^                ^          ^          ^                ^
   |                |          |          |                |
   |                |          |          |                |
   +----------------+----------+----------+----------------+
                (Artifacts flow between actions)
```

- **Source** pulls code (GitHub, CodeCommit, etc.) â†’ creates **Source artifact**.  
- **Build** (CodeBuild) compiles, packages, or containers â†’ **Build artifact**.  
- **Test** runs unit/integration tests; can be a Lambda or CodeBuild step.  
- **Deploy** pushes to target (ECS, EKS, Lambda, CloudFormation, etc.).  
- **Postâ€‘Deploy** can include canary testing, healthâ€‘checks, or manual approvals.

---  

### 5ï¸âƒ£ Best Practices  

#### âœ… Design & Structure
1. **Keep pipelines small & focused** â€“ one pipeline per service or logical component.  
2. **Separate concerns** â€“ use distinct **Source**, **Build**, **Test**, **Deploy** stages; avoid mixing build & deploy logic in a single action.  
3. **Use versioned artifacts** â€“ rely on commit SHA or semantic version tags; never overwrite previous artifacts.  
4. **Leverage **pipeline templates** (CodePipeline **Blue/Green** or **Canary** deployment configurations) to reduce custom code.  

#### âœ… Security
1. **Create dedicated IAM roles** for each pipeline (leastâ€‘privilege).  
2. **Store secrets** (DB passwords, API keys) in **AWS Secrets Manager** or **SSM Parameter Store**; reference them via **environment variables** or **parameter substitution** in actions.  
3. **Enable encryption at rest** for artifact buckets (S3 SSEâ€‘KMS).  
4. **Audit with CloudTrail** â€“ enable logging for all pipeline actions.  

#### âœ… CI/CD Efficiency
1. **Cache dependencies** in CodeBuild (e.g., `buildcache` environment variable) to speed up builds.  
2. **Use Docker images** that match your runtime (e.g., `aws/codebuild/standard:7.0` with `nodejs`, `python`, `java`).  
3. **Parallelize stages** when possible â€“ e.g., run unit tests and security scans concurrently.  
4. **Implement incremental builds** â€“ use **source versioning** and **cache** to avoid rebuilding unchanged parts.  

#### âœ… Deployment Strategies
| Strategy | When to Use | How to Implement |
|----------|------------|------------------|
| **Blue/Green** | Zeroâ€‘downtime, rollbackâ€‘friendly | Use **CodeDeploy** with `DeploymentConfig` = `CodeDeployDefault.AllAtOnce`. |
| **Canary** | Gradual traffic shift, risk mitigation | Use **CodeDeploy** with `Canary10Percent50Percent` or custom Lambda to shift traffic. |
| **Rolling** | Simple, works for most services | Default **CodeDeploy** behavior; can be tuned with `MaxBatchSize` and `PauseBetweenBatches`. |
| **Featureâ€‘flag gating** | Deploy code but keep feature hidden | Deploy to production, then enable flag via Lambda or SSM parameter; optionally add a **manual approval** stage. |

#### âœ… Monitoring & Observability
- **CloudWatch Metrics**: `PipelineExecutionStatus`, `PipelineExecutionFailed`, `ActionStatus`.  
- **CloudWatch Logs**: Enable **action logging** for detailed stepâ€‘byâ€‘step logs.  
- **Health Checks**: Add a **Postâ€‘Deploy** Lambda that pings endpoints or runs API tests; fail the pipeline if unhealthy.  
- **Alerting**: Create **SNS** topics or **EventBridge** rules to notify on failures.  

#### âœ… Cost Optimization
- **Reuse the same artifact bucket** across pipelines to avoid duplicate storage.  
- **Delete unused pipelines** and old artifact versions (set lifecycle rules on S3).  
- **Choose the right compute environment** for CodeBuild (e.g., `small` for quick builds, `large` only when needed).  
- **Turn off** CodeBuild containers after idle time (`idleTimeout` can be set to 0 to autoâ€‘stop).  

---  

### 6ï¸âƒ£ Common Pitfalls & How to Avoid Them  

| Pitfall | Symptom | Fix |
|---------|---------|-----|
| **Hardâ€‘coded IAM permissions** | Pipeline fails with â€œAccessDeniedâ€. | Use **managed policies** scoped to specific resources (e.g., `arn:aws:s3:::myâ€‘pipelineâ€‘artifacts/*`). |
| **Large artifact size** | Build times >â€¯30â€¯min, timeouts. | Keep artifacts under 100â€¯MB; use **S3 multipart upload**; split large payloads into multiple artifacts. |
| **Missing manual approval stage** | Production changes go straight to prod. | Add an **Approval** action before the **Deploy** stage for production releases. |
| **No version pinning** | Build breaks after upstream change. | Pin **runtime versions** (e.g., `nodejs:14.x`) in `buildspec.yml` or Docker image tags. |
| **Unencrypted secrets** | Security audit findings. | Move secrets to **Secrets Manager** and reference via **`SecretValue`** in actions. |
| **Pipeline drift** | UI changes diverge from code repo. | Store pipeline definition as **CodePipeline-as-Code** (e.g., CloudFormation, CDK, or JSON in a repo) and apply via CI. |
| **Unmonitored failures** | Silent pipeline stalls. | Enable **CloudWatch Alarms** on `PipelineExecutionFailed` and `ActionFailed` metrics. |

## 5ï¸âƒ£ Best Practices

### ğŸ“¦ Index Design
1. **Choose the right domain** â€“ it determines default field types (e.g., `DATE`, `PRICE`, `PRODUCT`). You can still add custom fields.
2. **Limit the number of indexes** â€“ each index incurs separate cost and latency; group related data sources logically.

### ğŸ“‚ Data Source & Document Preparation
1. **Enable extraction of metadata** â€“ for S3 objects, store metadata (title, author) in object tags or separate manifest files.

### ğŸ” Query & Ranking

### ğŸ” Security & Governance
1. **Apply leastâ€‘privilege IAM** â€“ grant Kendra read access only to the specific data sources it needs.

## 2. Key Concepts & Terminology

# Amazon Inspector â€“ Quickâ€‘Start Learning Guide  

**Audience:** Cloud engineers, security analysts, DevOps leads, and architects who want to harden their AWS workloads with automated vulnerability assessment.  

**Goal:** Understand what Amazon Inspector is, how it works, common useâ€‘cases, and the bestâ€‘practice steps to integrate it safely and efficiently into your CI/CD pipeline or manual inspection process.

## 1. What is Amazon Inspector?

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| **Fullyâ€‘managed security assessment service** | Scans EC2 instances, EBS volumes, and container images for software vulnerabilities and unintended network exposure. |
| **Ruleâ€‘based engine** | Uses *rules packages* (e.g., CIS benchmarks, PCIâ€‘DSS, custom AWSâ€‘provided or customerâ€‘provided rules) that are continuously updated by AWS. |
| **Findings & remediation guidance** | Returns a list of security findings with severity scores (Low/Medium/High/Critical) and remediation suggestions. |

| **Complianceâ€‘ready** | Generates evidence that can be exported to AWS Artifact for audit reporting. |

## 2. Core Concepts

| Concept | Explanation |
|---------|-------------|
| **Assessment target** | The EC2 instance, EBS volume, or container image you want Inspector to evaluate. |
| **Rules package** | A collection of preâ€‘written security rules. AWS provides >â€¯70 builtâ€‘in packages (e.g., `PCI_DSS`, `CIS_BASELINE`, `AWS_FOUNDATIONAL`). You can also import custom rules (JSON/YAML). |
| **Assessment template** | Defines *which* rules packages to apply, *which* resources to scan, and *how often* (e.g., `schedule: daily`). |
| **Findings** | The output items that indicate a security issue (e.g., â€œUbuntu 20.04 SSH port 22 open to 0.0.0.0/0â€). Each finding includes a severity, description, and remediation tip. |
| **Findings action** | You can set up EventBridge rules or SNS notifications to automatically trigger remediation workflows (e.g., stop an instance, quarantine a container). |
| **Assessment report** | JSON/HTML report that can be stored in S3, sent to CloudWatch Logs, or exported via AWS Artifact. |

---

## 3. Typical Useâ€‘Cases

| Useâ€‘Case | How Inspector fits in |
|----------|------------------------|
| **Continuous vulnerability scanning of EC2 fleet** | Schedule daily assessments on all instances (or a subset) â†’ feed findings into ticketing or autoâ€‘remediation. |
| **Hardening new AMIs before launch** | Include an *assessment template* in your AMI build pipeline (e.g., via EC2 launch template) to validate that the resulting AMI meets security baselines. |
| **Container image security** | Run Inspector on ECR images during CI/CD build â†’ block pushes that contain critical CVEs. |
| **Compliance evidence collection** | Export findings to AWS Artifact for PCIâ€‘DSS, HIPAA, or SOCâ€‘2 audits; combine with other AWS Config rules for a full compliance dashboard. |
| **Network exposure detection** | Inspector evaluates inbound port rules and can flag overly permissive security groups or public IPs. |
| **Shiftâ€‘left security in DevOps** | Add Inspector checks to pullâ€‘request pipelines; developers receive immediate feedback on insecure configurations before merging. |

---

## 4. Stepâ€‘byâ€‘Step Walkthrough (EC2)

1. **Create an Assessment Template**  
   ```json
   {
     "assessmentTargetArn": "arn:aws:inspector:us-east-1:123456789012:assessment-target/0a1b2c3d-4e5f-6g7h-8i9j-0k1l2m3n4o5p",
     "rulesPackageArns": [
       "arn:aws:inspector:us-east-1:123456789012:rules-package/0w1x2y3z-4a5b-6c7d-8e9f-0g1h2i3j4k5l"
     ],
   ```

2. **Create an Assessment Run**

3. **Wait for Completion** (usually <â€¯5â€¯min).  

4. **Retrieve Findings**

5. **Automate Remediation (optional)**

   - Or forward findings to **SNS** â†’ subscribe to a ticketing system.

---

## 5. Best Practices

| Category | Recommendation |
|----------|----------------|
| **Scope wisely** | Start with a *baseline* of critical instances (e.g., production web servers) before expanding to the entire fleet. |
| **Leverage builtâ€‘in rules packages** | Use AWSâ€‘provided packages for PCIâ€‘DSS, CIS, or NIST; they are vetted and updated automatically. |
| **Combine with AWS Config** | Use Config rules for *continuous compliance* and Inspector for *vulnerability scanning*; together they cover configuration drift and software flaws. |
| **Automate remediation** | Use EventBridge â†’ Lambda â†’ SSM Run Command to patch or isolate resources as soon as a critical finding appears. |
| **Tag resources for targeted scans** | Tag EC2 instances with `InspectorTarget=true` and reference the tag in the assessment target ARN â€“ makes onboarding new resources painless. |
| **Store findings securely** | Export findings to an encrypted S3 bucket and enable S3 Object Lock for immutable audit logs. |

| **Integrate with CI/CD** | For container images, add an Inspector step to your build pipeline (`aws ecr describe-images` â†’ `inspector start-assessment-run-for-image`). |
| **Review and act on findings** | Treat critical/criticalâ€‘high findings as *security tickets*; assign ownership; close the loop within a defined SLA (e.g., 24â€¯h). |

## 6. Common Pitfalls & How to Avoid Them

| **Too many findings â†’ alert fatigue** | Filter by severity, focus on critical/high, and use suppression groups for knownâ€‘good false positives. |
| **Assessment target not reachable** | Ensure the instance has an **outbound internet connection** (or VPC endpoint) to receive Inspector updates; also verify IAM role `InspectorServiceRole` is attached. |
| **Missing IAM permissions** | The service role used by Inspector must have `inspector:CreateAssessmentRun`, `inspector:BatchGetAssessmentFindings`, etc. |
| **Rules package not upâ€‘toâ€‘date** | AWS automatically updates rules; however, if you import custom rules, versionâ€‘pin them and review changes quarterly. |
| **Overâ€‘permissive network findings** | Combine Inspector network checks with AWS Network Firewall or Security GroupAnalyzer to remediate quickly. |
| **Finding data loss** | Export findings to S3 with versioning and retention policies; never delete findings before theyâ€™re archived for compliance. |

# AWSâ€¯Key Management Service (AWSâ€¯KMS) â€“ Quickâ€‘Start Learning Guide --- ## 1ï¸âƒ£ What is AWSâ€¯KMS? - **Fullyâ€‘managed, FIPSâ€‘140â€‘2/3â€‘compliant** keyâ€‘management service. - Lets you **create, store, rotate, and use** cryptographic keys (CMKs) for encrypting data across AWS services and applications. - Provides **auditâ€‘ready logging** (CloudTrail) and integrates tightly with other AWS services (S3, EBS, RDS, Secrets Manager, Lambda, etc.). --- ## 2ï¸âƒ£ Core Concepts | Concept | What It Is | Key Points | |---------|------------|------------| | **Customer Master Key (CMK)** | The primary key you own and manage. | â€¢ Can be **AWSâ€‘managed** (e.g., `aws/default`) or **customerâ€‘managed** (your own key).
